Ken,

   The common underlying thread is that unless adequate 
infrastructu=
re in in place, there is no way to even attempt anything 
other than that w=
hich fits within the confines of the 1-input/1-
output per node arena. That=
 has the appearance of RPSH (..round peg, 
square hole...).

   Cycling thr=
ough individuals of a population inside a single hidden 
node, and complexi=
fying around and through it between the current 
problem inputs and outputs=
, will quickly identify any benefit to be 
derived.

   The idea is that yo=
ur NEAT fundamental approach lends itself to 
ignore the portions of the ro=
und peg that does not fit in the current 
square hole, and then build in it=
's own corners around the portion of 
the round peg that did fit via comple=
xification. It is not a case of 
all or nothing.

   I believe it to be a f=
undamentally different and profoundly 
simpler approach to try what you hav=
e previously learned to determine 
if any has any benefit to the current pr=
oblem at hand, as opposed to 
attempting to identify fundamental repeating =
sub-structures for the 
purpose of re-application as "modules".

Thanks,
  =
 Andy Carl


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...> =
wrote:
>
> Andy,
> 
> It will be interesting to see whether taking a prior =
evolved 
network 
> and designating it as the function of a single node in =
a higher-
> level network will succeed.  My hunch is that this approach wil=
l be 
> more difficult to leverage than it may appear because it introduces=
 
> a brittle kind of hierarchy that is difficult for evolution to 
> optim=
ize.   The problem is that while such a new "module" may be 
> useful in so=
me contexts, there are more contexts where it is a 
round 
> peg in a squar=
e hole.  Because evolution has no a priori method for 
> knowing which case=
 is which, it will often place the module in an 
> unsuitable location.  
>=
 
> More generally, the risk can be summarized as introducing large 
> disc=
ontinuities into the search space.  Inserting a node that is 
> itself an e=
ntire ANN (perhaps even a very large substrate) is a 
> radical change that=
 will likely lead to a phenotype that is quite 
> different from its parent=
. 
> 
> The idea reminds me a bit of Joseph Reisinger's Modular NEAT, which=
 
> did show some promise, but suffered from a similar limitation.  
> Joe'=
s paper is here:
> 
> http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/keyword?reisinger:gecco04
> 
=
> In any case all new ideas involve some risk and if your gut 
instinct 
> =
tells you that risk can be overcome, it's still worth pursuing.
> 
> ken
> =
